conclusion: To determine whether the point O1 is to the right of point O, we need to consider the principles of refraction when light passes from air into water.
When light travels from a less dense medium (air) to a denser medium (water), it bends towards the normal (an imaginary line perpendicular to the boundary at the point of incidence).
The incident ray is the path of the light beam in the air before it hits the boundary. It travels from point A towards the boundary.

premise: When light enters water, it bends towards the normal.
conclusion: The refracted ray will pass through point B in the water.
Point O1 is where the incident ray meets the boundary between air and water.
Point O is the intersection of the straight line AB with the boundary.

premise: Since the light bends towards the normal when entering water, the refracted ray (towards B) will be closer to the normal than the incident ray.
conclusion: The incident ray must strike the boundary at a point O1 that is to the right of O because the refracted path through B is closer to the normal.

premise: Given the refraction principles and the geometry of the situation.
conclusion: Point O1 is indeed to the right of point O.
